intro: Trachyspermum pimpinelloides, commonly known as mountain cumin, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia and the Caucasus. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its seeds are aromatic and have been used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. Trachyspermum pimpinelloides thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or alpine environments.
